citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was a 2 yr old Bernese Mountain dog (Cooper, M, Tri color) that had some red inflamation in both ears with a small
amount of crusty brown/red material. The dog did not appear to be in any discomfort, however the ears had been cleaned
two days prior and showed signs that there may be an issue that needs medical treatment. The attending veterinarian had
not been advised of the ear condition at the time of the inspection.
Any medical condition that is not identified in a timely manner or communicated with the veterinarian could cause a
treatable condition to become chronic and cause unnecessary pain or discomfort to the regulated animal.
A veterinarian must be contacted for proper diagnosis and treatment for the regulated animal.
The veterinarian was contacted after the exit interview for an appointment the next day on December 19, 2023.

There were several 7006 dog disposition records of multiple litters that were missing the name and/or address of the
buyer to whom the regulated animals were sold or given to.
Complete dispositon records are required for proper management and traceability of the regulated animals.
The name and address of the person to whom a dog or cat was sold or given and that person's license or registration
number if he or she is licensed or registered under the Act must be provided on the 7006 disposition forms.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by February 16, 2024 (60 days counted from 1st RL
Inspection) or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to
schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There was a 2 yr old Bernese Mountain dog (Cooper, M, Tri color) that had some red inflamation in both ears with a small 
amount of crusty brown/red material. The dog did not appear to be in any discomfort, however the ears had been cleaned 
two days prior and showed signs that there may be an issue that needs medical treatment. The attending veterinarian had 
not been advised of the ear condition at the time of the inspection. 
 
Any medical condition that is not identified in a timely manner or communicated with the veterinarian could cause a 
treatable condition to become chronic and cause unnecessary pain or discomfort to the regulated animal. 
 
A veterinarian must be contacted for proper diagnosis and treatment for the regulated animal. 
 
 The veterinarian was contacted after the exit interview for an appointment the next day on December 19, 2023. 
2.75(a)(1)(iv) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There were several 7006 dog disposition records of multiple litters that were missing the name and/or address of the 
buyer to whom the regulated animals were sold or given to. 
 
Complete dispositon records are required for proper management and traceability of the regulated animals. 
 
The name and address of the person to whom a dog or cat was sold or given and that person's license or registration 
number if he or she is licensed or registered under the Act must be provided on the 7006 disposition forms. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by February 16, 2024 (60 days counted from 1st RL 
Inspection) or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to

schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
